mn40:5.3: Cp. Mn 12 and rajojalladhara at Thag 4.5, DN 25, DN 8, also see Sukhumattā chaviyā rajojallaṃ kāye na upalimpati at DN 30, etc.
mn40:5.9: BB’s incantations is a little harsh here. Manta in the suttas usually refers, not to magic, but to the Vedas.
mn40:10-12.6: Translating parḷāaha as fever here is incorrect. While in ancient Indian medicine it was obviously the same, in modern terms there is a distinction between physiological rise in body temperature due to fever, and illnesses induced by excessive heat. Since the condition here may be severe, but is alleviated by rest and cool water, it corresponds with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heat_exhaustion
